greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the sum k of such a subset of divisors of n with the largest sum and for which n-k and n-(sigma(n)-k) are relatively prime.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..25000
Index entries for sequences related to sigma(n)
example: For n=15, its divisors are [1, 3, 5, 15]. If we take the full set [1, 3, 5, 15] and its complement [], their sums are 24 and 0, but gcd(15-0, 24-15) = gcd(15, 9) = 3 > 1. If we take subsets [1] and [3, 5, 15], then their sums are 1 and 23, but gcd(15-1, 23-15) = gcd(14,8) = 2 > 1. If we take subsets [3] and [1, 5, 15], their sums are 3 and 21, but gcd(15-3, 21-15) = gcd(12, 6) = 6 > 1. Only when we take the subset with the four smallest sum, [1, 3] and its complement [5, 15], we get such sums 4 and 20 for which gcd(15-4, 20-15) = gcd(11, 5) = 1. Thus a(15) = 20, the size of the subset with larger sum.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, May 29 2019
